reference: Volume Five, Issue Forty-Five, File 15 of 28
title: Some Helpful VAX/VMS utilities
historical_context: This article provides insights into VAX/VMS utilities during a time when VAX systems were prevalent in enterprise environments, particularly in the late 1980s and early 1990s.
target_audience: VAX/VMS users, system administrators, and security researchers interested in legacy systems.
short_summary: The article introduces lesser-known utilities in the VAX/VMS operating system, focusing on commands like SHOW SYSTEM and MONITOR SYSTEM. It aims to help newcomers understand system processes and performance monitoring.
summary:
In this article, DARTH VADER presents a practical guide to some of the more obscure yet useful utilities available on the VAX/VMS operating system. The focus is on commands such as SHOW SYSTEM, which provides detailed information about the status of processes running on the system, including their state, priority, and resource usage. The author emphasizes the importance of understanding these commands for effective system management and troubleshooting, especially for those new to VMS. The article also introduces the MONITOR SYSTEM command, which offers a graphical representation of system performance data, making it easier for users to visualize and analyze system activity over time.

The author encourages readers to explore these utilities to gain a deeper understanding of the VAX/VMS environment, highlighting that many secrets and hidden functionalities exist within the system. By providing practical examples and command syntax, the article serves as a valuable resource for both novice and experienced users looking to enhance their operational knowledge of VAX/VMS systems. Overall, this piece contributes to the hacker culture by demystifying the complexities of VAX/VMS and empowering users to leverage its capabilities effectively.
